entry.title: Re: SAP PI integration with Magento
entry.content:
SAP PI can integrate with Magento using SOAP web services if the services support the necessary data exchange. Magento supports SOAP APIs, allowing SAP PI to consume or expose these services for data sync like orders, inventory, and customer info.

To integrate:

  1. Assess your integration needs and data flows.
  2. Ensure your SOAP web services cover required Magento API endpoints.
  3. Configure SAP PI to map and transform data between SAP and Magento.
  4. Test the data exchange thoroughly.
  5. Deploy and monitor the integration.

SOAP web services can support Magento integration through SAP PI, provided they are aligned with Magento’s API requirements and data formats. This setup will enable automation and real-time or batch data synchronization between Magento and SAP systems.

Hope this helps! If you have any doubts, feel free to ask.

entry.title: SuccessFactors Sales Performance Module
entry.content:
Driving Revenue Excellence with SAP Sales Performance Management

In today’s competitive landscape, organizations are increasingly relying on intelligent tools to optimize sales performance and align sales teams with business objectives. The SAP Sales Performance Management (SPM) module empowers companies to design, manage, and analyze their sales strategies with precision.

1. What is SAP SPM?
SAP SPM is an integrated solution that automates and streamlines key processes such as sales incentive management, territory and quota planning, and performance analytics. By eliminating manual processes and data silos, it ensures that sales teams stay motivated and aligned with company goals.

2. Core Capabilities:

  • Incentive Compensation Management: Automate commission calculations, ensure transparency, and reduce payment disputes.

  • Territory and Quota Planning: Optimize sales coverage and set achievable, data-driven quotas.

  • Analytics and Insights: Monitor performance in real time with dashboards that drive accountability and improvement.

3. Business Impact:
Organizations using SAP SPM report improved sales productivity, higher motivation, and faster decision-making. Integrating the module with SAP SuccessFactors or SAP CX solutions further enhances end-to-end visibility — from people performance to customer success.

4. The Future of Sales Enablement:
With built-in AI and predictive analytics, SAP SPM is evolving beyond automation to provide foresight — helping leaders forecast trends, identify performance gaps, and model the impact of incentive plan changes before implementation.

In summary, SAP Sales Performance Management transforms sales operations into a data-driven, transparent, and motivating ecosystem — driving both top-line growth and team engagement.

entry.title: Re: How to configure automatic G/L account selection for...
entry.content:
Hi seunabati,
As you explain when posting outgoing or incoming payments, after i choose bank account even though you’ve already set up the reconciliation account and linked it to the bank account. Please follow the step by step configuration as i show you below.

1. Bank Account Master Data (Manage Bank Accounts App)
In the bank account master record, you can assign:Main Bank Reconciliation Account (already done in your case). Payment Subaccounts for Incoming and Outgoing flows. These subaccounts are what the system uses to automatically post to the correct GL when you create payments.

2. Assign Payment Methods
Go to Manage Payment Methods for Company Code.
For each payment method (e.g., wire transfer, check, SEPA), assign: The Bank Account. The GL Subaccount (Incoming or Outgoing). This ensures that when you select a payment method, the system knows which GL account to hit.

3. Automatic Account Determination
In SSCUI (Self-Service Configuration UI) for Bank Accounting, check: Define House Banks and Account IDs → link the bank account ID to the reconciliation account and subaccounts. Define Posting Rules → specify which GL account is used for debit (outgoing) and credit (incoming).

4. Payment Transactions
When you post an outgoing payment, the system looks at: The payment method + bank account ID → derives the outgoing subaccount. When you post an incoming payment, the same logic applies but points to the incoming subaccount.

Hope you will get the issue resolved.

entry.title: Re: Breakdown analysis for equipment with no start-up dat...
entry.content:
Hello Javier Gómez,
At present, there is no configuration option in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (release 2508) that allows the Technical Object Breakdowns app to calculate results when the equipment start‑up date is blank. Even though SAP Note 3198903 states that the system should use the second notification as the start date, in practice the app requires the equipment master data to have a start‑up date maintained. I can sugguest you a workaround as mentioned below.

Maintain at least a dummy start‑up date in the equipment master record (for example, the installation date or earliest notification date).

Use variants and filters in the app to narrow down analysis once the start‑up date is set.

If you want SAP to enable the fallback logic described in the note, you would need to raise an incident with SAP Support referencing Note 3198903.

I also recommend you to always populate the equipment start‑up date in master data if you want breakdown analysis to work consistently. If this contradicts the expected behavior described in SAP documentation, open a support ticket so SAP can confirm whether this is a defect in release 2508 or an intentional design change.

Hope this workaround will help you. Please confirm if it worked

entry.title: Re: Loss of Employee Data in Candidate Profile After De-C...
entry.content:
Hi @samreen_fatima82 ,

This behaviour is standard SuccessFactors and expected:

When candidate is Internal

  • System maps Employee Profile → Candidate Profile using SM-Mapping.

  • Candidate inherits Employee ID, Rehire Status, Aadhaar etc.

When employee is Separated & becomes External

  • The Internal Candidate Profile is removed and converted back to External candidate.

  • During the De-Conversion, all Internal-only mapped fields are wiped, because:

    • SM-Mapping only works during Internal Conversion, not during De-Conversion.

    • Internal data is not stored on the External candidate object.

    • For data privacy, employee data isn't retained on an external candidate automatically.

There is no standard setting to “retain internal profile data after de-conversion.”

Feasible Solutions:

Below are the options customers typically use to retain this information.

OPTION 1 — Store the Data in Custom External Candidate Fields (Recommended)

Create custom external candidate fields (NOT internal-only fields) for:

  • Previous Employee ID

  • Previous Rehire Status

  • Previous Aadhaar Number

How it works:

  1. When internal candidate is created (Internal Conversion), SM-Mapping writes into these external fields.

  2. Because the fields belong to External Candidate entity, the values stay even after de-conversion.

Ensure your mapped fields are on the External Profile.

OPTION 2 — Use Business Rules (OnSave) to Copy Data to External Fields

Using business rules on the Candidate, you can:

  1. Create custom external fields

  2. Add a rule: OnSave of Internal candidate → copy Internal data → External fields

OPTION 3 — Use a Background Element (BC Element) That Belongs to External Profile

If you must store Aadhaar or history info:

  • Create a background element that belongs to External Candidate

  • Store internal details as history records (date-stamped)

This ensures nothing is lost during conversion.

Hope this helps!!

Thanks,

kr,

karthick.

entry.title: Automated Job Screening Using SAP Integration Suite, Adzuna, and ChatGPT
entry.content:
Idea

This exercise began as a practical way to explore SAP Integration Suite. Most job portals already provide alerts for new roles, but these alerts are usually driven by simple keyword matching. As a result, many of the recommended roles do not match the actual technical profile of the person receiving them.

The goal was to design an automated process that runs every few hours, retrieves SAP related roles from a job API, and then filters them using a model that understands a specific candidate profile. Instead of relying on keywords in the job title, the screening logic is based on how well each role aligns with a predefined set of technical strengths and preferences.

SAP Integration Suite acts as the orchestration layer. It calls the Adzuna job search API, identifies new job postings that were not seen in earlier runs, and sends each new role to a ChatGPT based classifier. That classifier has been configured using examples of roles that are a good fit and roles that are not, so its APPLY MAYBE and DO_NOT_APPLY decisions reflect the intended technical profile rather than generic matching. The integration flow then aggregates these outcomes into a single HTML formatted email with colour coding, making it easy to focus only on the roles that match that profile.


Overview

This prototype uses SAP Integration Suite to run a recurring process that retrieves SAP job postings, filters out previously seen entries, evaluates new roles with a classification model, and sends a summarized email after each run. The integration flow acts as the central engine that coordinates the API calls, manages state, and assembles the final output.

The flow begins with a scheduled trigger inside SAP Integration Suite. A set of request parameters is prepared for the Adzuna API including job keywords location and pagination details. The integration flow calls the API and receives a JSON response containing job postings for the current page.

The response is parsed to extract job attributes and job ids. A data store holds the list of job ids processed in earlier runs, and this list is used to filter out the roles already seen. Only new job entries continue through the rest of the flow.

For each new job the integration flow creates a structured input message and sends it to a ChatGPT model. The model reviews the job context and returns a category that reflects how well the role matches the defined criteria. The integration flow captures this classification and converts the job details into an HTML formatted block with colour coding.

As the run progresses, the integration flow builds a consolidated email body by appending one formatted block for each classified job. When all pages for the run have been processed or no more jobs are available, the integration flow updates the data store with the full set of seen job ids and sends the final email. If no new roles were identified during the run, the email contains a short message indicating that there were no new results.

Demo

 

Design Flow

The design flow reflects how the integration flow executes each step during a run and how the components work together.

  • A timer event triggers the integration flow at a defined schedule.
  • The integration flow prepares Adzuna request parameters including keywords location and the current page number.
  • The integration flow calls the Adzuna API and receives a JSON response.
  • A Groovy script parses the response and extracts the job details.
  • A data store entry is read to determine which job ids were processed earlier.
  • The integration flow filters the jobs and keeps only the ids that were not seen before.
  • For each new job the integration flow builds a structured classification request and sends it to the ChatGPT model.
  • The classification result is captured and formatted into an HTML block with colour coding.
  • The integration flow appends each formatted block to a single email body.
  • After all pages are processed the integration flow updates the data store with the latest job ids.
  • The integration flow sends a consolidated summary email that contains either the classified jobs or a message indicating no new results.

This design provides a repeatable cycle of fetch, filter, classify, and notify. It combines API connectivity, persistence, and model based evaluation without manual intervention.

Technical implementation

 

 

Main flow

  1. Start Timer
    A timer event triggers the flow according to the schedule. The event carries no payload. All runtime values are set in the next step.

  2. Init
    A content modifier provides the initial control values for the run. This includes
    • Adzuna request parameters such as what, what_or, where, results_per_page
    • The initial page number stored in header pagenumber
    • Technical properties such as emailBody, emailIndex, and the state entry id seen_entry_id
    These values guide the entire flow and are passed into the PageLoop.

  3. Get 1
    Reads the adzuna_state data store using the key seen_entry_id.
    If a state record exists, it contains a JSON list of previously processed job ids.
    If no record exists, the body is empty and NormalizeSeen handles that case.

  4. NormalizeSeen
    A Groovy script reads the data store body and converts it into a consistent JSON array.
    The script sets the output as a property called seen_json.
    This ensures all later steps read the stored state in the same structure regardless of whether it is the first run or a continued run.

  5. Looping Process Call 2
    Invokes the PageLoop subprocess repeatedly.
    The loop continues as long as the PageLoop sets the property hasMore to true.
    Each execution of PageLoop handles exactly one page of Adzuna results.

  6. SetMailBody
    After PageLoop finishes, the final emailBody property is moved into the message body.
    At this point emailBody contains either the full list of formatted jobs for this run or a single line stating that there were no new jobs.

  7. Mail
    Sends the email using HTML content type. The message body created in SetMailBody is delivered to the configured recipient.

PageLoop

  1. Start 1
    Receives runtime properties from the main flow such as pagenumber, results_per_page, and seen_json.
    These control how the page is fetched and how new job ids are detected.

  2. Request Reply 2
    Calls the Adzuna endpoint for the current page using
    • pagenumber
    • what and what_or keywords
    • results_per_page
    • Adzuna credentials
    The response is a JSON payload containing a list of job entries for this page.

  3. DecideAndNext
    A Groovy script that performs page processing. It
    • Parses the Adzuna JSON
    • Extracts job fields such as id, title, company, location, redirect URL, and description
    • Compares each id with the seen_json list from earlier
    • Creates a per page job queue containing only the new job entries
    • Updates seen_json to include all ids from this page
    • Determines if more pages exist based on results_per_page and the number of entries returned
    • Sets hasMore to control whether PageLoop should execute again

  4. JobLoop
    A local process that iterates over job_queue_json created by DecideAndNext.
    Each job in the queue is classified by the model.
    When job_queue_index reaches job_queue_size, JobLoop ends.

  5. PAGE STORAGE
    Writes the CSV representation of this page into the adzuna_jobs data store.
    The entry id is based on run_id and the current page number.
    This allows keeping a historical snapshot of the raw Adzuna response.

  6. SeenToBody
    A Groovy script that moves the updated seen_json into the message body.
    This prepares the body for the next data store write.

  7. STATE STORAGE
    Writes the updated seen_json list back into the adzuna_state data store under seen_entry_id.
    This allows the next scheduled run to continue with the correct state of previously processed job ids.

  8. End 1
    PageLoop finishes and returns control to the Looping Process in the main flow.
    If hasMore is true, PageLoop is invoked again for the next page.
    If hasMore is false, the loop exits.

JobLoop

  1. Start 2
    Begins with the properties populated in DecideAndNext.
    job_queue_json contains all new jobs that were found on this page.
    job_queue_index starts at zero.

  2. NextJobFromQueue
    A Groovy script that reads job_queue_json, extracts the next job based on job_queue_index, and exposes the job fields as
    one_job_id
    one_job_title
    one_job_company
    one_job_location
    one_job_description
    one_job_url
    If job_queue_index equals job_queue_size, the script signals the loop to exit.

  3. BuildChatGPTRequest
    A content modifier builds a full JSON request body using the job fields and the classification prompt.
    The structure includes system and user messages and instructs the model to return APPLY, DO_NOT_APPLY, or MAYBE.

  4. HTTP to ChatGPT
    The HTTP receiver sends the request to the OpenAI endpoint with the Authorization header set to the configured API key.
    The response contains the generated classification in the field choices[0].message.content.

  5. ExtractChatGPTResponse
    A Groovy script parses the model response, trims the content, and standardises it into one of the three valid categories.
    The output is written into the property classification.

  6. AppendToEmailBody
    A Groovy script formats the job and classification into an HTML block.
    The classification is colour coded based on the returned category.
    The block is appended to emailBody and emailIndex is incremented.

  7. BuildClassifiedRecord
    A script or content modifier builds a compact representation of the classified job.
    Common fields include id, title, company, location, classification, and redirect URL.

  8. write_adzuna_classified
    Writes the classified job into the adzuna_classified data store using id as the key.
    Overwrite is enabled so that if the same id appears again, the new classification replaces the old one.

  9. End 2
    Returns control to the JobLoop wrapper.
    If job_queue_index is less than job_queue_size, JobLoop runs again for the next job.
    If all jobs are processed, JobLoop ends and PageLoop continues with state updates.

 

ChatGPT Model:

{"messages":[
{"role":"system","content":"You are a strict classifier for a senior SAP technical professional. Their skills include ABAP, Fiori, BTP, CAP, RAP, CDS, AMDP, CPI, HANA, S4, and technical leadership. They want SAP developer, development architect, or technical lead roles, not functional or business analyst roles. When the user sends job text, respond with exactly one of these three words and nothing else: APPLY, DO_NOT_APPLY, MAYBE."},
{"role":"user","content":"Job description: SAP SuccessFactors functional consultant focusing on employee central and talent modules. The role is focused on HR processes and configuration rather than technical development."},
{"role":"assistant","content":"DO_NOT_APPLY"}
]}

{"messages":[
{"role":"system","content":"You are a strict classifier for a senior SAP technical professional. Their skills include ABAP, Fiori, BTP, CAP, RAP, CDS, AMDP, CPI, HANA, S4, and technical leadership. They want SAP developer, development architect, or technical lead roles, not functional or business analyst roles. When the user sends job text, respond with exactly one of these three words and nothing else: APPLY, DO_NOT_APPLY, MAYBE."},
{"role":"user","content":"Job description: Senior SAP BTP architect focusing on CAP, RAP, CDS, event driven integration, and leading a team of developers."},
{"role":"assistant","content":"APPLY"}
]}

This is a fine tuning training sample for an OpenAI model. Each line in the JSONL file represents one supervised example. It contains a system instruction, a user input, and the expected assistant output.

The system message defines the rules for classification, the user message contains a job description, and the assistant message holds the correct category. A full training file contains many such examples, which helps the model learn how to consistently return the categories APPLY, DO_NOT_APPLY, or MAYBE.

Result

Jobs are classified according to the profile.

References

Adzuna Job Search API: https://developer.adzuna.com/activedocs#!/adzuna/search

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/cpi-gmail-smtp-integration/ba-p/13457193

Conclusion

This prototype shows how SAP Integration Suite an external job search API and a classification model can work together to create a repeatable automated process. The integration flow retrieves new SAP roles filters out previously seen entries evaluates each role through a lightweight model and sends a clear summary after every run. It gives a practical example of scheduled processing state management and controlled use of generative AI inside an integration flow.

The exercise helped in understanding how the integration flow behaves when combined with external APIs and model based logic and how small design adjustments influence stability and accuracy. It shows how integration tools and AI techniques can complement each other in a simple and maintainable way.

Disclaimer

This is a prototype created for learning purposes. Functional gaps and bugs may exist. SAP guidelines best practices coding standards authorisation requirements and performance considerations were not in scope. A real solution would require proper error handling security checks resilience measures and alignment with enterprise development standards.

entry.title: Re: Change the procurement type from E to F
entry.content:
Hi,
if you are changing the procurement type in SAP MM Transaction OMD9 (from E = In-house production to F = External procurement) will not impact existing material masters. It only affects the default procurement type for new material masters created in the future under that material type. Existing materials retain whatever procurement type was set in their master data unless you manually update them.

entry.title: Re: MMAM tcode in test mode
entry.content:
Hi,
You cannot rollback after the call transaction because, the transaction MMAM (Change Material Type) contains its own COMMIT WORK. When you use CALL TRANSACTION or batch input, that commit is executed inside the transaction itself. Once the commit is executed, the LUW (Logical Unit of Work) is closed, and you cannot roll it back from your report program. That’s why your attempt to wrap it in your own rollback logic fails — the database changes are already persisted. Unfortunately, you cannot override SAP’s commit behavior in standard transactions.

One thing is possible if you use BAPIs or function modules instead of MMAM.
Many SAP transactions have underlying BAPIs or function modules that perform the same logic but leave commit control to the caller. For material master changes, find BAPI BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA (general material changes) BAPI_MATERIAL_MAINTAINDATA (more flexible, newer)

These BAPIs do not commit automatically. You can call them multiple times, then decide whether to COMMIT WORK or ROLLBACK WORK.

This can be one workaround. Let me know if you need any more suggestion

entry.title: Create code list restriction in SAP Sales , Service and Enterprise Service Management
entry.content:
Code list restrictions are a key part of keeping data clean in SAP CX systems. They work by making sure a specific field only accepts values from a predefined list. This is incredibly helpful for standardizing how information is entered and ensuring consistency across your entire organization. In this post, we'll walk through exactly how to set these restrictions up and put them to work in SAP CX Systems.

Code list restrictions can be divided into two types.

  • Instance based code list restriction.
  • Role based code list restriction.

Instance based code list restriction.

In instance based code list restriction , if you want to restrict any code list with some control field you can use instance based code list restriction.

  • You define a restricted field (the code list to be restricted)
  • You specify a controlling field that determines which values are available
  • When users select a value in the controlling field, only relevant options appear in the restricted field

Example - If you want to control Cash discount term code with the Distribution channel you can choose code to restrict field as 

Cash discount term code and control field as Distribution channel.

Role based code list restriction

In role based code list restriction you can restrict code list based on the user roles.

  • You define which values are appropriate for specific user roles
  • The system checks the logged-in user's role assignments
  • Only values permitted for the user's roles are displayed in the selection options

Example- You can control Case type based on the logged in user role.

Help link- https://help.sap.com/docs/CX_NG_SVC/56436b4e8fa84dc8b4408c7795a012c4/fb2b10068bf446778fe65eb539133b37.html

entry.title: How S/4HANA Finance Improves Working Capital and Cash Flow Forecasting
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Finance is designed to meet this demand. With a unified data model, real-time analytics, and embedded machine learning, S/4HANA allows organizations to optimize cash flows, shorten the cash conversion cycle, and generate more reliable short- and long-term forecasts. This article explains how S/4HANA Finance enhances working capital management and elevates liquidity forecasting to a strategic level.

Understanding Working Capital in the S/4HANA Context

Working capital represents the liquidity a company needs to run daily operations and typically revolves around three core areas:

  • Accounts Receivable (AR)
  • Accounts Payable (AP)
  • Inventory

Traditional ERP systems treat these components in separate modules, which leads to fragmented data, manual reconciliations, and delays in visibility. Forecasts often rely on spreadsheets, batch jobs, and outdated data.

S/4HANA changes this paradigm with its Universal Journal, which consolidates financial, controlling, asset, and material ledger data into a single real-time table (ACDOCA). This eliminates reconciliation gaps and allows finance teams to analyze working capital KPIs instantly, based on the latest actuals.

Key S/4HANA Finance Features That Transform Working Capital Management

1. Universal Journal (ACDOCA): One Source of Truth

The Universal Journal is the structural backbone of S/4HANA Finance. Instead of posting to multiple tables, the system records all financial and controlling details in a single line item.

This creates several advantages:

  • Real-time visibility into receivables, payables, and inventory values
  • Instant KPI calculation (DSO, DPO, DIO, cash conversion cycle)
  • No batch jobs or reconciliation between FI and CO
  • Faster month-end closing cycles

With unified data, AR aging, AP commitments, and inventory levels are always up to date—giving finance teams the foundation needed for accurate working capital optimization.

  1. Real-Time Analytics & Embedded Fiori Apps

S/4HANA enables finance users to track working capital trends through pre-built Fiori apps and embedded analytics. These tools provide interactive, drill-down dashboards for:

  • Overdue receivables
  • Collection effectiveness
  • Payables due within a specific period
  • Supplier liabilities and payment block analysis
  • Material inventory aging
  • Cash discount utilization

Having access to real-time analytics allows business leaders to act faster and with more precision. For example, AR teams can prioritize high-risk customers, while procurement teams can renegotiate terms with suppliers who consistently affect DPO.

  1. Integration Across Finance, Sales, Procurement & Inventory

Working capital management is not only a finance responsibility—it touches end-to-end business processes:

  • Order-to-Cash (OTC) influences receivables and DSO
  • Procure-to-Pay (P2P) determines payables, DPO, and cash disbursement timing
  • Manufacturing and inventory directly affect stock levels and DIO

S/4HANA integrates these processes natively. Finance teams no longer need to gather data across modules or rely on operational teams for manual updates. Instead, S/4HANA provides a consolidated view of all working capital drivers, enabling data-driven decisions that reduce the cash conversion cycle.

  1. Embedded Machine Learning for Collections and Credit Management

One of the biggest working capital challenges is unpredictable customer payment behavior. S/4HANA addresses this with machine-learning-powered scoring models that improve:

  • Payment date prediction
  • Dunning prioritization
  • Dispute resolution
  • Credit risk assessment

ML algorithms analyze historical transactions and customer habits to forecast when invoices will likely be paid. As a result, AR teams can focus their efforts on accounts that significantly affect liquidity. Better collections performance directly improves working capital and reduces reliance on credit lines.

How S/4HANA Finance Enhances Cash Flow Forecasting

Cash flow forecasting remains one of the most strategic activities in corporate finance. However, many organizations still rely on static spreadsheets and delayed financial data. S/4HANA Finance replaces this manual approach with real-time liquidity insights.

1. Real-Time Cash Position & Liquidity Planning

The updated Cash Management module in S/4HANA provides:

  • Cash Position: short-term cash visibility based on actual bank balances, open items, and expected incoming/outgoing payments
  • Liquidity Forecast: mid-term visibility incorporating sales orders, purchase orders, planned investments, and recurring payments

These views allow treasury teams to understand liquidity needs and avoid unnecessary borrowing or inefficient cash sitting idle.

2. Treasury Integration for Holistic Liquidity Management

S/4HANA integrates seamlessly with SAP Treasury and Risk Management (TRM), enabling companies to include treasury exposures—such as loans, FX hedges, derivatives, and interest payments—directly in liquidity forecasts.

The One Exposure from Operations framework consolidates:

  • AR and AP
  • Bank statements
  • Treasury transactions
  • FX and commodity exposures
  • In-house cash positions

This unified approach ensures liquidity forecasts reflect all cash movements across the business.

3. Predictive Analytics & Machine Learning-Enhanced Forecasts

S/4HANA Finance and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) can apply predictive models to estimate future cash flows based on:

  • Historical patterns
  • Seasonality
  • Customer payment behavior
  • Supplier payment trends
  • Sales cycles
  • Market conditions

Machine learning continuously refines these predictions, improving forecast accuracy over time and providing early warnings when liquidity risks emerge.

4. Bank Communication & Real-Time Reconciliation

S/4HANA supports API-based bank communication, replacing manual statement uploads or batch processes. Real-time bank integration improves:

  • Visibility of actual bank balances
  • Automation of reconciliations
  • Cash concentration processes
  • Liquidity categorization

Because cash balances update continuously, forecasts remain accurate throughout the day.

Practical Use Cases and Business Impact

Use Case 1: Reduced DSO Through Predictive Collections

A manufacturing company using S/4HANA’s ML-based payment prediction identifies customers at high risk of late payment. The AR team prioritizes those accounts for dunning and personalized follow-up.

Impact:

  • Lower DSO
  • Improved cash inflows
  • Stronger working capital position

Use Case 2: Optimizing AP to Improve DPO

With S/4HANA’s real-time AP analysis, a global distributor identifies suppliers who consistently offer favorable cash terms but whose invoices are being paid early. The organization adjusts payment runs accordingly.

Impact:

  • DPO increases
  • Reduced early payment leakage
  • Improved short-term liquidity

Use Case 3: Inventory Right-Sizing

An international retailer uses S/4HANA’s integration between materials management and finance to track inventory carrying costs and aging in real time. Procurement adjusts safety stock levels and reduces slow-moving items.

Impact:

  • Lower inventory carrying costs
  • Better capital utilization
  • Shorter cash conversion cycle

Use Case 4: Real-Time Liquidity Forecast for CFOs

A multinational company consolidates all global entities into S/4HANA’s Cash Management and Treasury modules. CFOs receive a real-time forecast of liquidity across currencies, banks, and regions.

Impact:

  • Strategic optimization of borrowing and investment
  • Faster decision-making for hedging and cash pooling
  • Reduced risk exposure

Implementation Considerations

To maximize the benefits of S/4HANA for working capital and liquidity management, organizations should consider:

1. Clean and Consistent Master Data

Accurate customer, vendor, and material master data directly impacts AR, AP, and inventory visibility. Data quality initiatives are essential.

2. Use of SAP Analytics Cloud (Optional but Recommended)

For advanced planning, simulation, and predictive analytics, SAC offers extended forecasting capabilities.

3. Organizational Alignment

Working capital touches multiple departments. Aligning finance, sales, procurement, supply chain, and treasury is critical.

4. Training on Fiori Apps and Real-Time Dashboards

Even the most sophisticated tools require strong user adoption. Teams should be trained to make full use of S/4HANA’s analytics and automation features.

Conclusion

S/4HANA Finance transforms working capital and cash flow forecasting from manual, reactive processes into dynamic, real-time capabilities. With its unified data model, embedded analytics, automation features, and machine learning enhancements, S/4HANA empowers finance teams to make faster, more informed decisions that strengthen liquidity, reduce operational risk, and improve overall financial performance.

For CFOs and finance leaders looking to build resilience and agility, S/4HANA Finance is not just an upgrade—it is a strategic enabler for modern working capital excellence.

entry.title: 3ZB Billing Costs Between Companies error ME124 Material Subject to Inventory
entry.content:
Hi,

Update: My below question is resolved with help of note 3049571. When I use a finished product (material type FERT) instead of a service product (material type SERV), the purchase order, sales order, billing document and supplier invoice are processed successfully. The 3ZB test script instruction to use a service product seems to be incorrect.

I am trying to enable best practice scope item 3ZB "Billing of Costs Between Affiliated Companies" in S/4HANA Public version 2508 according to the corresponding setup guide (CBC path: Sales > Sales Business Portfolio > Intercompany Sales > Set Up Billing of Costs Between Affiliated Companies ).

When creating a Purchase Order for the service product the following error message is raised: "Material not subj. to inventory mgmt. in plant 3720 (Pl. check your input) - Message no. ME124. There is no data for plant 3720 (plant/storage location stock view) in
the material master record." Plant 3720 is the buying/receiving plant in the PO item. The supplier of the PO is another company.

This error should not happen because this scenario is about service purchasing, so inventory is not relevant.

The product is defined with material type SERV (PO Item field Product Type Group = 2 Service). SSCUI 103539 "Define Attributes of Material Types" shows that no quantity and value update take place for SERV as expected.

Account assignment of the purchase order item is cost center and goods receipt indicator is switched off.  

I noticed that the same issue was addressed in question 3ZB Billing Cost between companies is not working but unfortunately it is not explained here what solution was applied to overcome this issue "There is no data for plant XXXX (plant/storage location stock view) in the material master record". 

@HenrikeGrtecke , @adrian321 , can you please share what correction actions were taken to solve the issue?

Note 3049571 "Material Not Subj. to Inventory Mgmt. in Plant( Intercompany Stock Transfer Process with SERV in Purchase Order)" says that "in the standard system the stock transport is not possible for non-stock material types like SERV". But in the test script of scope item 3ZB SERV material SM0001 "Service Material 01" from Master Data Scripts (MDS) 31X Create Product Master of type "Service Product"  is used. Is this an error in the best practice test script?

entry.title: Integrations as part of the SAP LeanIX (Enterprise) Architecture?
entry.content:
We may have our state-of-the-art Applications. But how do we make them work together? We may have all our Date Objects properly designed and governed. But how do we unlock it for the Users and Agents?

Integration – key is in the Integration Services!

We have to integrate Applications, Users and Agents – in order to unlock our Data and make our Business Processes run seamlessly and efficiently, cross whole Enterprise.

I’ve talked about importance of recognizing the work on integrations in the Enterprise Architecture domain (my article in SAP EA Community: Enterprise Architecture for integration?), but now let’s go with few practical examples…

Integrations @ EAM

If we use SAP LeanIX solutions[1] as EAM (Enterprise Architecture Management) tool, and we want to model our Enterprise Architecture – how do we manage it, if we do not “connect” the dots

Well, we cannot!

Figure 1. Integration Services

Of course, integrations are far more complex than just “connecting” dots. In this example, I’ve used an example where we replicate Business Partner Customers to two order taking channels – fairly common scenario in Omnichannel Sales.

  • Source is Master Data System (i.e. SAP MDG) – this is clearly marked as an Application in SAP LeanIX.(of course, we may have multiple Applications within one “box”, but overall object modeling is a different story, not covered by this article…).
  • Target Systems are B2B Channel and Field Sales – again I am color-coding those as Applications.
  • From Source to Target Systems, we are replicating Customer – this is Data Object.
  • Finally, we have an Interface (if we use SAP LeanIX notation), or Integration Service (in a broader sense). We may be “happy” in seeing “only” one line, representing BP Customer Replication. connecting Source and Target Systems… This is probably sufficient for high-level C4[2] diagramming and modeling.
  • However, if we want more details on Interfaces (or dots “connecting” Applications) – i.e. how it actually works, what are the underlying technology and capabilities, which patters were used etc. – then we must go few levels “below” in the integration hierarchy. Each “parent” Interface (or Integration Service). has one or more “child” Interface Components (or Integration Service Components) – i.e. APIs, IFlows, Queues etc.; and those “child” Interface Components “uses” some IT Components – i.e. SAP CPI, API-M, Azure Service Bus etc.

Figure 2. SAP LeanIX Interface Fact Sheet

In SAP LeanIX each object is modeled with its own Fact Sheet, thus each Interface, whether “parent” or “child”, has its Fact Sheet. There are some powerful features when defining Fact Sheets:

  • We are defining descriptions, attributes, and we also have a possibility to add links to external resources – i.e. we may have external repositories with functional and technical details in Azure DevOps Wikis or GitHub..
  • We can link Interface with its “parent” or “child:
  • We can link Interfaces among themselves into “left/right” flow.
  • We can link with appropriate Application(s), Data Object(s) and IT Component(s)

Interesting though is to note, general recommendation in SAP LeanIX is to use Applications for Business Applications, while Technical Applications (like SAP Integration Suite etc.), enabling specific Interfaces, we should model as IT Components. Although there is no strict limitation preventing us to set i.e. SAP Integration Suite as an Application (this will of course create different pictures in C4 diagrams), the important thing is to choose the approach “once” and stay consistent.

Figure 3. Integration model

Object models with connected Interfaces can very easily become very complex. But do we really have a choice – not to model full integrations? Is it sufficient to have only high-level Enterprise Architecture in EAM tool?

I guess it all depends on the preferences, but I would say – no, it is not sufficient.

And it’s not about – “hey SAP LeanIX give us possibility to model Interfaces in more granularity” – this is about overall management of the Enterprise Architecture. How can we manage something we do not see? And yes, integration is really a key, or a backbone, of daily operations of any Enterprise:

  • The Architect View(point) must include sufficient level of details on all Architectural components – otherwise we are “blind” in seeing AS-IS state.
  • Building new or reusing existing integrations cannot be made without appropriate visibility on the underlaying layers of the Interface(s) or Integration Service(s) – otherwise we cannot make educated decision for TO-BE state
  • If we do not have adequate view on AS-IS and TO-BE, we cannot properly understand the Gap and build roadmap, planning and strategy.

Integrations @ EA Frameworks

Ups looks like no Integration Architecture domain in TOGAF©[2]?

Figure 4. Where is Integration Architecture

Where is Integration Architecture domain?

  • Is it part of B. Business Architecture? Probably not, but aren’t we saying that integrations are enabling Integrated Business Processes…
  • Maybe it’s part of C. Information System Architecture, also (usually) split into Application Architecture and Data Architecture? Looks reasonable to be “somewhere” here, but still, it’s not “formally” listed here…
  • Or is it D. Technology Architecture? Integrations are often observed as “technology” domain, but this is not entirely correct perception…

Hold on, nothing is “carved in stone”…

Figure 5. LeanIX Application and Data Architecture

Interfaces (or Integration Services) should be observed on the same level as Applications and Data Objects – and in SAP LeanIX metamodel[3], indeed we do see that Interface(s) are part of Application and Data Architecture.

  • Application “provides” and/or “consumes” Interface.
  • Interface “transfers” Data Object.

Integrations are not just dots or lines – it’s much more, no matter if we observe some underlaying IPaaS or Event Broker as an IT Component or an Application. And if we accept these guidelines, then we have to “pay” attention to model integrations correctly and fully.

Simple and clear…

Integrations @ AI use-cases?

First “reply” would be – yes of course. But let’s think where we are heading with AI…

MCP Serves can be built on tables – accessing Data Objects directly. It can be done, yes, but do we want this or would we prefer some sort of governance by exposing Data Objects via OData and API Management in between? That is the question yet to be answered… But I know my answer. Of course, in the "world" of Microsoft Dynamic365, MCP Servers are actually based on Dataverse object or tables (not APIs) but this is different, I guess…

Now, what about A2A (Agent-to-Agent)? This is also some sort of integration… Well, if it is integration, it is an integration – “things” are not being integrated on its own... 

Why am I bringing AI? AI is now “mixing and matching” with everything. While AI Agents and Agentic AI will most certainly impact integration technology, the need to precisely “craft” Integration Services will not disappear. It may change, but it will not disappear!

Putting this in the EAM perspective – yes of course we do want to manage all out AI investments, ideally in one EAM tool, and SAP LeanIX now comes with AI agent hub[4] – equipped to discover, manage and govern all AI agents. Of course, A2A and MCP are somehow inevitable part of it. Another reason to model integrations correctly and fully... 

Integration is the key!

Integration, whether it is fully Decoupled Integration based on Event-Driven Architecture principles supporting Compostable Business (Architecture)[5], or it is some more legacy SOA[6] – in all cases, it is Integration Services which are making things “happen”.

So, it’s a glue connecting Application Blocks, right?

No, no – it’s not “just” a glue! It used to be a “real” glue – well at least in legacy solutions, connecting monolithic “boxes”. But now we are Agile, we are building Systems to be “Compossible”. If Applications are Blocks (one can imagine its LEGO©[7] or equivalent), we don’t want to glue Blocks, because we cannot “recompose” our System of Blocks into something different, we cannot change Blocks, and or try new Blocks..

This “glue” we use is invisible it is by design – its Blocks itself – the way how we build them to “fit” – no matter of their particular shape, or size or color, they can always fit. They can fit “tight” but can be “disassembled” at any time we need to “recompose” the System of Blocks.

Sounds simple, but it’s not.

If we want that flexibility, if we want to avoid “fixing” with glue – we need to design and build with precision. And this is more than just technology stack – this is also about overall strategy – what kind of Blocks we need to connect now, or in future. How do we “craft” integrations so everything can fit – not only now. but in foreseeable future as well.

Who are we?

We are Developers – yes (this is our usual background)! We are Engineers – yes (most certainly)! But we are seasoned Architects – yes as well, very seasoned (if I may add)!

We are versatile Architects who need to know, or at least understand, so many different “things” – not only integration technologies, but Data Models, Applications, even Business Processes. After all, we are not integrating Applications and Systems, we are integrating Business (Processes).

Figure 6. Work of EA for Integration

We can be Solution Architects or Enterprise Architect, just as in any domain – but we must be able to understand much more than “just” integration technology.

Is our work perceived that way? Well, this is a different story…

And again – Integration Services…

I am being subjective – yes. But haven’t I proved how important integration is?

Is the integration work seen and valued as any other Enterprise Architecture work? Very rarely, as integration is usually seen as very technical discipline, part of solutioning, not strategy… There are exceptions (obviously)… 

Maybe we need to raise the awareness and change the mindset – proper integration modeling and design is the key for the success in many initiatives – and proper modeling has to come as a result of the Integration Strategy, not just "technical" solutioning on case-to-case basis.  

Am I giving too much “credit” to integrations? Yes, but with a reason… Just think, how many projects failed or were delayed because integrations were not properly designed or implemented? And this (usually) has nothing to do with “bad” integration developers and integration engineers… 

Does this resonate?

Acknowledgment

*) Into image generated by AI.

References

[1] SAP LeanIX: https://www.leanix.net/en/

[2] C4 model: https://c4model.com/

[3] SAP LeanIX Interface Modeling Guidelines: https://help.sap.com/docs/leanix/ea/interface-modeling-guidelines

[4] SAP LeanIX AI agent hub: https://www.leanix.net/en/ai-agent-hub-in-sap-leanix

[5] Composable Architecture: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/what-is-composable-architecture/ba-p/13889670

[6] SOA: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-architecture-blog-posts/agile-ea-from-soa-to-interoperability/ba-p/225234

[7] LEGO©: https://www.lego.com/

entry.title: Dynamic Quotation Attribute Analytics in SAP CPQ
entry.content:
SAP CPQ supports advanced analytics and visualization directly from your product and quotation data, enabling sales and business leaders to drive decisions with real-time insights. By leveraging SAP CPQ's scripting capabilities, users can programmatically query system tables, such as context.Quote or Quote and Product, to aggregate key attribute data—for example, tracking the number of quotes generated for different product types or configurations.

 

How to Generate Analytics and Graphs

To produce meaningful visualizations, use the following approach:

  • Query product and quotation data: Use scripting (IronPython) within SAP CPQ to run queries against system tables. For instance, fetch the count of quotations grouped by a specific product attribute (like type or power rating) for each quarter.

  • Assemble data for visualization: Transform the queried results into chart-ready arrays representing, for example, quarterly counts for each product configuration.

  • Integrate with visualization services: Use an API like QuickChart to render a bar chart. Script-generated data can be sent to the QuickChart REST API, returning a chart image that can be embedded in quote dashboards, emails, or management reports.

 

quickchart_url = 'https://quickchart.io/chart/create'
post_data = {
    'chart': {
        'type': 'bar',
        'data': {
            'labels': ['Q1', 'Q2', 'Q3', 'Q4'],
            'datasets': [
                {'label': 'Centrifugal', 'data': [70, 95, 89, 104]},
                {'label': 'Submersible', 'data': [40, 30, 38, 42]},
                {'label': 'Gear', 'data': [12, 18, 22, 17]}
            ]
        }
    }
}

response = RestClient.Post(quickchart_url, post_data)


After running the Python or SAP CPQ server-side code to generate your chart using the QuickChart API, the API response contains a URL where the rendered graph can be accessed.

You can use this URL in any document or reporting output. For instance, if you need to embed the chart in a generated HTML document or email from SAP CPQ, simply include an HTML image tag like this:

<img width='800px' height='400px' id='lineChart' src="https://quickchart.io/chart/render/sf-610928f3-3854-4266-a8ea-6fc6d8662ce6">

This approach allows you to dynamically visualize attribute-based analytics (such as quote counts by pump type, quarter, or any product dimension) within your business documents, dashboards, or customer-facing communications—all powered directly from your SAP CPQ or external system workflows.

entry.title: Re: FI_OT_DNC001 message
entry.content:
Dear @Andrea_Gr,

Message class FI_IT_DNC = „Messages for document numbering checks in Italy, I assume so”.

That means:

This error is part of the Italian document-numbering / ODN date-control logic.

On S/4HANA Cloud public edition, there are two different situations:

  1. If the other customer also has an Italian company code (country = IT)

Then you can get the same message there but only by activating the same Official Document Numbering (ODN) with date control.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4603118feda9495892abadbe8f8c3d14/b15cfc3e56404640af4458ff9a16eb38.html

There is no separate message control in Public Cloud, the only way to get FI_IT_DNC001 is to have the Italian ODN date-control active for that company code/doc type.

In this case the correct and supported way is to build your own check that behaves, for example:

Using the validation apps (no coding)

  1. Open Fiori app “Manage Substitution/Validation Rules”
  2. Open an existing Validation rule or create a new one.
  3. In General Information:
    • Set Control Level = Error or Warning.
    • Click value help on the Message field.
  4. In the popup:
    • Message ID/number
    • Short text (what user will see)
    • Severity (error/warning)
    • Choose Create
    • Enter:
    • Save.
  5. Back in the rule, select this new message in Message.

Now this custom text will appear when the validation fails.

More details below:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F4406')/S35

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/e6175604fc874bfe84aa14d2f9ae1fbd/5c8c2825535f4e3aa9b7f716a0085221.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/ac7785b7870344a8998c8492c0cd5c3d.html

Using a Badi:

  1. App Custom Logic find a Badi for FI document validation
  2. Implement logic, for example: FIN_ACDOC_HEADER_VALIDATION

 

    • Read posting date from the incoming document.
    • Compare with system date
    • If posting date > today and your other conditions are met raise an error message.

Summary:

  • FI_IT_DNC001 is Italian document-numbering date control not a generic message.
  • For non-Italian company codes, you cannot turn on FI_IT_DNC001 itself; instead, create a custom validation that blocks future posting dates and shows your own error text.

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Workflow event trace ACTIVE but doesn't trace anything (transactions SWELS/SWEL)
entry.content:
I had a discussion with SAP Support about the design of SWELS screen. It's only possible to make SAP improve the screen by proposing an idea in the influence Web site.

But I can't find an "opportunity/campaign" where to suggest the idea... (the best one I could find is about SAP Build https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/campaign/2281) If anyone knows where to suggest, please tell me.

So, for those interested, I'm posting here an implicit enhancement at the beginning of the subroutine PBO_100 of the program RSWELSWITCH, which displays a message indicating the "actual activation" state.

If the date and time restrictions will make the trace virtually inactive in less than one hour, a message shows when the trace becomes inactive:

If the date and time restrictions make the trace virtually inactive now, a message clearly indicates the information:

Implicit enhancement at the beginning of the subroutine PBO_100 of the program RSWELSWITCH:

DATA:
  BEGIN OF zz,
    evtlog      TYPE swelcfg-evtlog,
    now         TYPE timestamp,
    swelcf      TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF swelcf WITH EMPTY KEY,
    line_swelcf TYPE REF TO swelcf,
    s_date      TYPE RANGE OF d,
    s_time      TYPE RANGE OF t,
    s_tstp      TYPE RANGE OF timestampl,
    active_now  TYPE abap_bool,
    datlo       TYPE syst-datlo,
    timlo       TYPE syst-timlo,
    duration    TYPE i,
    timestamp   TYPE timestamp,
"""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""$"$\SE:(3) FORM PBO_100, Début, Extension ZZSRO_RSWELSWITCH, Stru. ZZ, Fin                                                                                   S
  END OF zz.
SELECT SINGLE EVTLOG FROM SWELCFG INTO @zz-evtlog.
IF    zz-evtlog      = 'X'
  AND g_limit_trace IS INITIAL.
  GET TIME STAMP FIELD zz-now.
  SELECT * FROM SWELCF INTO TABLE @zz-swelcf.
  LOOP AT zz-swelcf REFERENCE INTO zz-line_swelcf.
    CASE zz-line_swelcf->selfield.
      WHEN 'S_DATE'. " before note 3461138
        INSERT VALUE #( sign   = zz-line_swelcf->sign
                        option = zz-line_swelcf->opt
                        low    = zz-line_swelcf->low
                        high   = zz-line_swelcf->high )
               INTO TABLE zz-s_date.
      WHEN 'S_TIME'. " before note 3461138
        INSERT VALUE #( sign   = zz-line_swelcf->sign
                        option = zz-line_swelcf->opt
                        low    = zz-line_swelcf->low
                        high   = zz-line_swelcf->high )
               INTO TABLE zz-s_time.
      WHEN 'S_TSTP'. " since note 3461138
        INSERT VALUE #( sign   = zz-line_swelcf->sign
                        option = zz-line_swelcf->opt
                        low    = zz-line_swelcf->low
                        high   = zz-line_swelcf->high )
               INTO TABLE zz-s_tstp.
    ENDCASE.
  ENDLOOP.

  zz-active_now = abap_false.
  IF zz-s_tstp IS NOT INITIAL.
    GET TIME STAMP FIELD zz-now.
    IF zz-now IN zz-s_tstp.
      zz-active_now = abap_true.
    ENDIF.
  ELSE.
    GET TIME.
    zz-datlo = sy-datlo.
    zz-timlo = sy-timlo.
    IF zz-datlo IN zz-s_date AND zz-timlo IN zz-s_time.
      zz-active_now = abap_true.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.

  IF zz-active_now = abap_true.
    zz-duration = 1.
    WHILE zz-duration <= 3600.
      IF zz-s_tstp IS NOT INITIAL.
        zz-timestamp = cl_abap_tstmp=>add( tstmp = zz-now
                                           secs  = zz-duration ).
        IF zz-timestamp NOT IN zz-s_tstp.
          g_limit_trace = 'X'.
          EXIT.
        ENDIF.
      ELSE.
        zz-timlo = zz-timlo + 1.
        IF zz-timlo = '000000'.
          zz-datlo = zz-datlo + 1.
        ENDIF.
        IF NOT ( zz-datlo IN zz-s_date AND zz-timlo IN zz-s_time ).
          g_limit_trace = 'X'.
          EXIT.
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
      zz-duration = zz-duration + 1.
    ENDWHILE.

    IF g_limit_trace = 'X'.
      g_limit_trace = |Trace deactivated in { CONV t( zz-duration ) TIME = USER } hours|.
    ENDIF.
  ELSE.
    g_limit_trace = 'Trace in fact INACTIVE due to date/time restrictions'.
  ENDIF.
ENDIF.

Note that the code considers the situation of RSWELSWITCH working with or without the note 3461138 - SWEL: Event doesn't appear in Event Trace - SAP for Me. Before the fix, the date and time restrictions are stored according to the user's local time zone (lines S_DATE and S_TIME in the table SWELCF), and after the fix they are stored according to the UTC time zone (S_TSTP).

entry.title: Re: S/4 Hana public cloud - Key User - Create Custom Tile...
entry.content:
Dear @LEOIER,

With only the Custom Tiles app and a Custom Data Browser you cannot make one dynamic tile that automatically adapts across DEV / TEST / PROD in Public Cloud.

The correct key-user way to expose a custom CDS view as a tile is to treat it as embedded analytics and publish it via Custom Analytical Queries, not via a URL tile.

Recommended approach (key-user, cloud-friendly)

Assuming your CDS is for reporting / display of data the clean way in Public Cloud is:

  1. Open Custom CDS Views.
  2. Create a new view (YY1_…):
    • Set Scenario = Analytical Cube/Dimension

 

    • Choose the primary data source (I_* view or your existing custom CDS)
  1. Add associations, elements, and calculated fields as needed.
  2. Publish the CDS.

Use Custom Analytical Queries app

  1. Open Custom Analytical Queries.
  2. Create New:
    • Query Name: YY1_YOURNAME
    • Data Source: your analytical cube CDS
  3. In tabs:
    • Field Selection – choose dimensions/measures.
    • Display – put fields on rows/columns, configure measures.
    • Filters – set fixed filters and user input filters.
  4. Save then Publish the query.

Now you have a proper analytical query object that is already „tile-ready”

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/33f3a229ecfe438ca6b2053c48b4e1bb.html

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-s-4hana-cloud-embedded-analytics-custom-analytical-queries/ba-p/13738288

Publish the query as a tile

From the Custom Analytical Queries:

  • Open your query and hit Preview.
  • In the preview view, use the Share menu:
    • Option 1: Save as Tile (personal) – good for your own testing.

 

    • Option 2 (recommended for others): In many latest setups you use Manage KPIs and Reports / Custom Analytical Queries and Services to formally publish the query and create a tile linked to a business catalog.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/4ef099d254cd4f8a96df001496f53952.html

Put the tile into a business catalog (Custom Catalog Extensions)

Use Custom Catalog Extensions

  1. Open Custom Catalog Extensions.
  2. Choose or create a customer business catalog where you want the tile.
  3. Add your newly created analytical app / tile to that catalog.
  4. Make sure that catalog is assigned to a business role

Users with that role will now see your tile on their Launchpad.

More details below:

https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-custom-ui-generate-tile..html

https://community.sap.com/t5/financial-management-q-a/how-to-check-business-catalog-to-be-assigned-for-custom-in-app-application/qaq-p/13682231

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-s-4hana-embedded-analytics-user-roles/ba-p/13518142

Transport to TEST / PROD (dynamic across systems)

Because you’re using only in-app key user objects:

  • Custom CDS View
  • Custom Analytical Queries
  • Tile / Catalog Extension

You can move them by Export Software Collection app from. That’s what makes it effectively dynamic per system in S/4HANA Cloud.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/6896de5f70c54753ac028f444eafa16f.html

Best Regards,

Dawid

docker run --mac-address 02:42:ac:11:00:12 --sysctl kernel.shmmni=32768 --ulimit nofile=1048576:1048576 --stop-timeout 3600 -i --name a4h --restart=always -h vhcala4hci -p 3200:3200 -p 3300:3300 -p 8443:8443 -p 30213:30213 -p 50000:50000 -p 50001:50001 sapse/abap-cloud-developer-trial:2023 -skip-limits-check -agree-to-sap-license

entry.title: Re: Investment Boost: A significant step to promote economic growth
entry.content:
Hi Bino,

Many thanks for this info. I have followed the set-up for straight line and the have an issue with the resultant ordinary depreciation for subsequent acquisitions in that the depreciation is calculating on the depreciation start date of the original acquisition i.e. all acquisitions in the year will depreciate for the full year. In our case we want ordinary depreciation to be calculated based on the asset value date of the subsequent acquisitions.

I then changed the period control for the ordinary depreciation phase 1 to a key that has the ‘calculate depreciation from the asset value date’ indicator set.  That though then results in the special depreciation doubling up.

Could you please advise on how to overcome this?

Many thanks

entry.title: Re: Investment Boost: A significant step to promote economic growth
entry.content:
Hi Bino, 

What I omitted previously is that we depreciate based on stated percentages rather than useful life.

Cheers

entry.title: Customer Confirmation on Proof of Delivery
entry.content:
Hi All

The SAP provided proof of delivery processing allows you to record what the customer has indicated as the actual receipt of goods so that the customer can only be invoiced based on the PoD processed for the customer.

However, there seems to be no functionality / text available where a customer's confirmation number / verification number can be stored in the underlying delivery document when the POD is processed. That could lead to conflicts as there is no place to have a customer confirmation number be captured in the delivery when the POD is processed.

How do we capture the customer's POD reference and Date on the POD transaction ?

Appreciate your help

Regards

Rohit Zalani

entry.title: Introducing LinkedIn Recruiter System Connect with SAP SuccessFactors: Integrated Hiring Made Easy
entry.content:
We’re thrilled to announce the launch of Recruiter System Connect (RSC) with SAP Success Factors, a powerful integration designed to transform how talent acquisition teams work. This collaboration brings together the power of LinkedIn Recruiter and SAP’s enterprise-grade applicant tracking capabilities, creating a seamless experience for recruiters and hiring managers.

Why This Matters

Recruiting today is complex. Teams often juggle multiple systems, leading to inefficiencies, duplicated efforts, and inconsistent candidate data. RSC solves these challenges by connecting LinkedIn Recruiter directly with your SAP SuccessFactors ATS, enabling real-time data synchronization and streamlined workflows.

Key Benefits for Joint Customers

  • Unified Candidate Data: Access consistent, up-to-date candidate information across LinkedIn Recruiter and SAP. No more toggling between platforms or dealing with outdated records.
  • Faster, Smarter Hiring Decisions: With bi-directional syncing, recruiters can see applicant history, interview feedback, and hiring outcomes directly in LinkedIn Recruiter. This means better-informed outreach and reduced risk of duplicate engagement.
  • Improved Candidate Experience: By eliminating redundant steps and ensuring recruiters have full context, candidates enjoy a smoother, more personalized journey.
  • Time Savings and Efficiency: Customers using RSC report saving up to 3.5 hours per recruiter per week by reducing manual data entry and platform switching.
  • Free to Activate: Like all LinkedIn integrations, RSC is free to activate—delivering immediate ROI without additional cost.

Learn about all of the 2H 2025 Release Highlights for SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting.

entry.title: 2H 2025 - 'Latest People Profile' Unable to customise categories
entry.content:
We are deciding to disable the ‘Latest People Profile’ configuration until our current version is no longer available (1H 2026)

Two main reasons:

Unable to customise categories (Doesn’t meet accessibility standards)

  • The font and colour of categories cannot be modified. By default, the font is black. This means that the current version of the ‘Latest People Profile’ does not meet the WCAG standards of a minimum contrast ratio of 4:5:1. Please see example below:  ( Attached Screen Shots)

No support for ‘Shout Outs’ / Badges

  • We customer at Dept of Community Justice and other agencies utilise shout outs for the current profile. When enabling the latest people profile, this is no longer available on the profile.
  • This is only available on ‘Spotlight’. Could this be added to the full profile too?

entry.title: The Procurement Monthly - November 2025
entry.content:
Contents

Summary. 1

Raindrop. 1

Zip State of spend. 2

S&P Outlook. 2

AQPC. 3

McKinsey. 3

Icertis. 3

 

Summary

Across these reports, three trends stand out:

  • Flexible, agile procurement operating models are the new competitive differentiator.
  • AI and analytics drive efficiency and resilience but require deliberate strategy, skills investment, and integration.
  • Contract and supply chain complexity demand advanced intelligence platforms and process automation.

Procurement leaders should prioritize business-aligned technology adoption, scenario-based planning, and cross-functional talent development. Process and organizational design must emphasize agility and strategic value, deploying orchestration and AI tools wherever possible. Agility and digital mastery will define the winners

Raindrop

An interesting report that discusses how Procurement and finance leaders face a major gap between their ambitions around agility and AI innovation, and their ability to deliver real change. Raindrop’s survey of 1,000 U.S. decision-makers shows 73 percent prioritize flexibility, yet only 27 percent feel empowered to innovate, and a staggering 18 percent have not adopted any AI in procurement. Legacy cost-focused mindsets, slow institutional buy-in, outdated technology, and skills shortages block progress. The COVID pandemic and subsequent shocks (Ukraine, Panama Canal, shipping crises) forced abrupt changes. Many teams found themselves unprepared—40 percent endured severe delays, and years spent prioritizing cost savings over digital capability left organizations exposed.

AI adoption is limited but promising. Only 15 percent have embraced advanced tools, yet over 80 percent see themselves responsible for innovation. Barriers include culture, investment, and skills gaps, not system readiness alone. The report insists that flexibility in procurement is no longer optional. It must be linked to strategic business outcomes, not just cost or risk metrics. AI’s best opportunities—in data analysis, automation, collaboration, and risk management—free talent for strategic work. Leaders should measure procurement not only by savings but alignment with growth, supplier relationships, and business enablement. The future will favour those who move rapidly to adopt AI, change executive perceptions, and partner with proven technology providers to close readiness gaps. Practical next steps: invest in AI-native platforms, upgrade talent, and restructure incentives around flexibility and strategic impact. Flexibility, combined with AI, is now the critical foundation for future-proof procurement.

Zip State of spend

Zip’s global survey of 1,030 procurement and finance leaders reveals that AI already shapes how businesses plan, hire, and spend. 67 % use AI in spend and supplier management, with 17 % deploying it widely. The shift is broad: processes are moving digital, tech stacks are fragmenting, and spend priorities shift from goods to people-based services, especially professional services, consultancy, and contingent labour. Nearly three-quarters now factor AI capability into hiring decisions, and IT headcount is projected to rise, while procurement teams remain flat or shrink in large organizations.

Despite strong optimism around AI, execution lags. Most leaders feel somewhat prepared but lack defined strategies, skills, and operational governance. The top skills for future procurement are AI fluency, data analytics, and supplier collaboration. Smaller companies embrace best-of-breed and orchestration approaches; large enterprises consolidate and await incumbent vendor innovation. Leaders cite inflexible processes as the single biggest barrier to procurement’s influence; modernization and automation are urgent.

Spend control and tech strategy must reflect this landscape. Procurement leaders should prioritize data architecture for orchestration, embrace hybrid tech stacks, and focus savings on people-related services. The next three years require deliberate investment in talent, process redesign, and adoption of orchestration technologies. AI will reshape operating models, but success depends on business alignment and technology readiness

S&P Outlook

According to S&P’s latest report the Q4 2025 supply chain outlook is dominated by uncertainty: tariffs, trade reviews, and sector-specific duty changes disrupt global flows. U.S. duties remain in flux—from emergency (IEEPA) programs to Section 232 and 301 reviews impacting electronics, medical supplies, and aerospace. Trade activity is slowing; October saw a 0.4 percent drop year-over-year, with weak growth forecasts (1.7 percent for 2026). Container shipping volumes contract sharply, affecting supply chain costs and timelines. Corporate profits globally have taken a $900 billion hit from supply disruptions and tariffs since January. Firms pass higher costs to consumers selectively, negotiate with suppliers for cost sharing, and delay long-term investments in favour of tactical responses.

Regulatory complexity in the U.S., EU, and Asia persists, with ongoing legal cases and shifting exemptions constantly redrawing the risk map. Climate, cyber, and conflict risks add further stress. The report highlights sustained tactical decision-making, with little strategic investment until more policy clarity arrives. Vertically integrated firms have more resilience, but weak supply chains see margin expectations fall by up to 140 basis points. Procurement leaders should focus on cost modelling, flexible sourcing, and contract renegotiation to weather the ongoing uncertainty. Develop deeper supplier relationships, optimize for agility, and watch labour cost structures when considering reshoring options

AQPC

This reports covers the top use cases and benefits of AI adoption in procurement which according to their research remains limited.

58% of surveyed organizations have yet to implement it, but those that have report substantial results. The top three use cases: spend analysis (78%), sourcing insights, and pricing intelligence. AI tools automate spend classification, detect anomalies, and forecast spend. They support supplier discovery, scenario modelling, and help manage price fluctuations, renegotiation, and total cost of ownership evaluations. Benefits include improved data quality (80 % see gains), stronger decision making, increased savings, scaled expertise, and reduced contract leakage.

AI enables higher data accuracy, proactive risk management, and process automation. It lets procurement functions standardize contracts, analyse risky terms, and respond faster to business changes. For SAP and engineering leaders, invest in data integration, model governance, and real-time analytics. Procurement teams should experiment with guided onboarding, contract risk analysis, and predictive tools. The report urges firms to address privacy and ethics, manage verification, and prepare robust governance to maximize AI benefits

McKinsey

This article which takes data from several surveys, suggests that Procurement functions face a “perfect storm” combining macro volatility and digital disruption. Managed spend per FTE is up 50% over five years; expectations and complexity have grown. AI agents promise radical gains—potentially driving 25–40 % efficiency improvements by shifting non-strategic work to automation. Leading firms create hybrid workforces where procurement professionals partner with digital agents, freeing time for strategy.

Organizational maturity correlates with profitability. Strategic category management, dedicated centres of excellence, and advanced analytics drive tangible value (five percentage points or more in EBITDA margin for leaders). Examples include firms saving 10–20% on costs after redesigning category and sourcing models, deploying AI for invoice reconciliation, and leveraging COEs for process excellence.

Attendees at McKinsey’s CPO Forum cite stress, talent, and digital enablement as top priorities. Many still underuse procure-to-pay, SRM, and e-sourcing tools. The best advice: separate strategic and transactional roles, build out COEs, invest in AI and data analytics, and elevate procurement to a central, business-driving function. Process automation is the bedrock of the reimagined procurement organization

Icertis

According to this viewpoint from Icertis, Rising tariff complexity forces procurement teams to rethink contract management and sourcing strategies. The report argues that contract intelligence is critical for navigating cost increases, compliance, and supply disruptions brought by rapidly changing trade policies. CFOs now cite tariffs as their top concern, up 270 % this year. Practical responses include pull-forward sourcing, stockpiling, shifting production, and contract renegotiation.

Their key advice: audit contracts to identify price adjustment, termination, and hardship clauses. Incoterms, fixed-price, and price adjustment clauses determine who bears tariff costs and ability to renegotiate. Organizations need centralized and AI-enabled contract intelligence to surface critical terms quickly. The average large enterprise has contract data in 24 systems, leading to poor visibility and missed opportunities—up to 70% of contract value is lost to obligations not tracked.

Icertis showcases AI-driven workflows for renegotiation, onboarding new suppliers, and compliance management. SAP leaders should integrate contract intelligence platforms to automate workflows and harmonize terms with ERP systems. The agile use of contract insights ensures rapid, strategic responses to new tariffs and mitigates risk

 

As always reach out to discuss more, and always happy to hear your thoughts!
